questions.text: A rose gardener following prick injury develops the following skin changes. What is the causative agent:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sporothrix schenckii The given clinical picture shows erythematous nodules spread along lymphatic channel is of Sporotrichosis.

Highyeild:

Sporotrichosis: A Subcutaneous mycosis is aka rose gardener's disease Causative organism : Dimorphic fungi S . Schenckii Lives on vegetations Diagnosis: The fungus is present in the tissue, usually in the form of small (3–5 μm) cigar‐shaped or oval yeasts, and these may, on occasion, be surrounded by a thick, radiate, eosinophilic substance that forms the distinctive asteroid bodies. Culture- At 25°C yeast is converted to mold form- Rosette of conidiophores Treatment: Itraconazole, potassium iodide

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Histoplasma: It causes histoplasmosis, a systemic fungal infection that is acquired by inhalation of fungal spores from soil contaminated with bird or bat droppings. Option C. Sarcoptes scabies: It is a mite that causes scabies, a highly contagious skin infestation characterized by intense itching and a papular rash. Option D. Paracoccidioides marneffei: It causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a systemic fungal infection that is endemic in parts of Central and South America.

questions.text: Patients presented with these vesicular lesions distributed on a single dermatome, and also complains of pain over the region. Which of the following is the most probable cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes zoster The given clinical picture is of Shingles/ Herpes zoster It occurs in secondary infection with Varicella zoster virus e reactivation of latent varicella zoster from dorsal root ganglion after primary infection- chicken pox Characteristics: Unilateral lesion Dermatomal involvement- most common T3 to L3 spinal segment Mucous membrane within the Derma tome is affected Painful, grouped vesicles over red base Triggers for herpes zoster include Emotional stress Use of medications (immunosuppressants) Acute or chronic illness Exposure to the virus Presence of a malignancy Complication: Post Herpetic neuralgia Treatment: Amitriptyline, pregabalin, gabapentin Antiviral for painful zoster- High dose acyclovir started as early as possible 800 mg 5 times/day for 1 week

Highyeild:

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus: Nerve involved: Frontal branch of ophthalmic nerve (V1) Vesicles present over tip/side of nose = corneal involvement present Herpes zoster oticus: Aka Ramsay hunt syndrome Geniculate ganglion is involved Vesicles over the external auditory canal I/L facial nerve palsy and otalgia present.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. HIV: It can cause various skin lesions, but the presentation of vesicular lesions distributed on a single dermatome is not typical for HIV. Option B. Herpes simplex: It can cause vesicular lesions, but it typically presents with multiple clusters of vesicles on or around the lips, mouth, or genitals. It is not common for herpes simplex to cause vesicular lesions in a single dermatome. Option C. Lymphangioma: These are benign malformations of lymphatic vessels that can cause a mass or swelling, but they do not typically cause vesicular lesions or pain.

questions.text: A 68-year-old with tense itchy blisters that ruptured after a few days to leave a hemorrhagic crust. Image shown. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bullous pemphigoid History of tense itchy blisters which settle down after a while is consistent with the diagnosis of Bullous Pemphigoid.

Highyeild:

Bullous pemphigoid It is an immunobullous disease that typically occurs in patients older than 60 years of age . Target protein: Hemidesmosome Target antigen: BPAG1, BPAG2 Characteristic of the lesion: large, tense blisters arising on normal skin or an erythematous or urticarial base. Site : flexural surfaces , the lower abdomen, and the thigh. Oral lesions in 10 to 30% of cases. Nikolsky and Asboe-Hansen signs are negative. Histopathology : subepidermal blister with predominantly eosinophilic and neutrophilic infiltrate. DIF : shows deposits of linear IgG and C3 along the basement membrane.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris: It is a rare autoimmune blistering skin disease that typically presents with intraepidermal blisters that rupture easily, leaving behind painful erosions.. Option C. IgA pemphigoid: It is another autoimmune blistering skin disease that is characterized by the deposition of IgA antibodies in the skin. It typically presents with large, tense blisters that occur in a linear distribution. Option D. Dermatitis herpetiformis: It is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) in more than 90% of cases. It presents as groups of small, red, itchy bumps and blisters, which are usually distributed symmetrically on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and back.

questions.text: A child presented with a whitish lesion on the elbow and penile shaft as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lichen nitidus The given clinical picture shows pinpoint to pinhead‐sized, flesh-colored, with a flat, shiny surface. papules are of lichen nitidus. It is an inflammatory skin disease that presents as localized, tiny, skin-colored bumps in children involving the flexor aspects of the forearm, backs of hands, penis, chest, abdomen, and buttocks. Can also involve the face . Histopathological findings: Discrete lymphohistiocytic infiltrate expanding 1 - 4 dermal papillae Epidermal collarette gives the classic ball and claw appearance (90% of cases) Multinucleated giant cells (foreign body or Touton-type ) often present Overlying hyperkeratosis with or without parakeratosis is seen. Basal layer vacuolation and colloid bodies may be prominent

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Lichen Planus: It is a chronic inflammatory disorder that affects the skin and mucous membranes, and it typically presents with small, flat-topped, polygonal bumps that can be white, pink, or purple in color Option B. Scabies: It is a contagious skin condition caused by a mite, and it typically presents with burrows or linear tracks on the skin, as well as small red bumps and intense itching. Option D. Lichen scrofulosorum: It is a rare skin condition that is associated with tuberculosis infection and typically presents with small, reddish-brown bumps that are found on the chest, back, and arms.

Table:

#MANTRA Lichen Nitidus vs Lichen planus Feature Lichen Nitidus Lichen Planus Lesion appearance Small, shiny, flesh-colored papules Small, flat-topped, polygonal papules or plaques Lesion distribution Often localized to the trunk and limbs Can occur anywhere on the body, but often on wrists, ankles, lower back, and genital area Itching May be mild to severe Often itchy Age of onset Typically childhood or young adulthood Typically middle-aged or older adults Association with autoimmune disease Uncommon More common, particularly with oral lichen planus Histology Granulomatous inflammation around hair follicles Hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and lymphocytic infiltration of the epidermis and dermis Treatment Often resolves on its own within a few years Topical or systemic corticosteroids, phototherapy, or other immunosuppressive therapies

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient from Bihar presented with hypopigmented macules over the neck. There is no hypoaesthesia or nerve thickening. History of prolonged fever and nodular lesions on the face in childhood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PKDL Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis is PKDL (Post-Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis). PKDL is a dermatological manifestation that occurs as a sequela of Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis) , which is caused by a parasite transmitted by sandflies. Bihar is an endemic region for Kala-azar, which increases the likelihood of PKDL diagnosis. The history of prolonged fever and nodular lesions on the face in childhood is also suggestive of a previous infection with visceral leishmaniasis. Features: It presents with hypopigmented or erythematous macules, papules, nodules or plaques , usually located on the face, neck, arms, and trunk . The lesions may be itchy, but are usually painless, and there is no nerve thickening or hypoaesthesia. Macular lesions on the legs Macular lesions on the legs

Highyeild:

Leishmaniasis: Clinical features Species Visceral Leishmaniasis Fever, visceromegaly, pancytopenia L.Donovani Cutaneous Leishmaniasis Multiple nodules or ulcers of the skin that spontaneously heals by fibrosis ( oriental sore) L. tropica L.major L.mexicana Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis Similar to cutaneous but lesions occurs at mucocutaneous junction- oral and nasal mucosa ( espundia ) L.braziliensis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Atopic dermatitis: It is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by pruritic eczematous skin lesions, often located on the flexor surfaces of the body. Option B. Tuberculosis: It may also present with skin lesions, but the absence of any other specific findings, such as systemic symptoms or radiographic findings, makes it less likely. Option C. Tuberculoid leprosy: It presents with well-demarcated hypo-pigmented patches, usually with anesthetic areas and nerve thickening.

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: C. Indeterminate leprosy resolves more often than tuberculoid
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Indeterminate leprosy resolves more often than tuberculoid Spontaneous remission is much more common in indeterminate leprosy (75%) than in tuberculoid leprosy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. About 85-90% of patients do not resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure. Option B. Spontaneous remission indeed occurs in leprosy but is variable in children; hence cannot be considered to be more common in adults, where a fixed value can be easily seen. Option C. Spontaneous remission does occur in indeterminate leprosy.
